awd_titl_txt: Workshop Proposal: Analog Modeling of Tectonic Processes 2019: Memphis, TN - November 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a workshop award which will gather leading gescientists who use numerical models, which are computer simulation, and analog models, which are physical representations of Earth processes. The workshop will allow researchers from these two areas to work on similar problems and discuss the strengths and weaknesses of both appraoches as well as to share their best practices and compare their approaches to modeling. This is expected to encourage the modeling community to gain familiarity with different approaches and to foster new collaborations. The broader impacts of the workshop include support for students and early career researchers, especially those from underrepresented groups in science to participate. In addition, these models are valuable in the classroom setting, and the workshop will incorporate and share curriculum materials.

Both analog and numerical modeling are valuable methods of understanding tectonic processes. This workshop will bring together the analog and numerical research communities to provide a forum for discussion and deliberately and thoughtfully provoke discussion of similar scenarios modeled by both analog and numerical techniques. They will run three experiments to benchmark modeling capabilities in different tectonic settings. The gathered research groups will model the same scenario and discuss boundary conditions and the strengths and weaknesses of each approach. The workshop will provide an opportunity for researchers to share some of their best practices and compare and contrast different approaches. The workshop will take place November 12-14, 2019. This project is supported by the Tectonics program and Earthcube programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Earth scientists in the field of tectonics often employ modeling methods to understand how geological structures form and evolve. Computer simulation is one popular modeling method and another is to conduct lab experiments with materials like sands and clays, collectively called analogs. While both modeling methods are valuable tools for tectonics, they frequently produce results that must be carefully reconciled not only with field observations but with each other. Small and widely dispersed, the analog and numerical tectonic modeling communities in the US have found such reconciliation challenging. As a community-wide effort to improve the situation, a biennial workshop series, Analog Modeling of Tectonic Processes (AMTP), has been organized. The AMTP workshop supported by this grant was originally planned for 2019 but deferred by one year and held virtually in 2020 due to the cautionary measures required by the COVID-19 pandemic.

The overarching aim of the AMTP Workshop 2020 (hereafter AMTP 2020) was to continue to bring together the analog modeling community in the US and provide a forum for discussion. AMTP 2020 was held as a virtual event for two days, September 15-16, 2020 via Zoom, a video conferencing service. The diverse group of 91 participants consisted of U.S. and international senior and early-career researchers as well as graduate and undergraduate students. Six plenary talks were presented. Two of them introduced recent studies on strike-slip systems that involved analog modeling or have implications for the modeling approach. Two talks with similar scopes focused on the extensional tectonic systems. The fifth invited presentation shared the lessons the organizers of Sedimentary Experimentalist Network learned from their community-building effort. The last invited presentation introduced analog and numerical modeling for hydrothermal systems in the crust near mid-ocean ridges. The breakout session sparked brainstorming among the participants on organizing the community of analog and numerical tectonic modelers, good practices for data storage and archiving and enhancing reproducibility. Twelve posters were submitted and made available for downloading and browsing on figshare.com, an online data repository service, before the workshop started. During the workshop, the poster presenters introduced their work as a lightening (less then 5 minutes long) talk and interacted with participants in breakout rooms provided by Zoom. Finally, in a breakout discussion, the participants exchanged useful information about good practices and future directions in data management and reproducible experiments.

The workshop promoted the involvement of graduate students and early-career researchers. By adding analog and numerical modeling skills to their research toolbox, these researchers will be better equipped to perform experiments and/or utilize analog modeling results to address future research questions. The online collections of the invited presentations and posters were much appreciated by asynchronous participants. They are available for public access at the following web addresses: Digital poster collection at https://figshare.com/s/e373ed70e0e43086bf04; and the recorded invited talks at https://figshare.com/s/fe142626824c1657519b.
